conclusion: Use the ideal gas law PV = nRT to determine the temperature at state C.
Explanation of variables in the ideal gas law: P is pressure, V is volume, n is number of moles, R is ideal gas constant, T is temperature in Kelvin.
Temperature at state A is given as 27°C.
Convert temperature from Celsius to Kelvin using T(K) = T(°C) + 273.15.
Temperature at state A is 300.15 K after conversion.
From the p-V diagram: At state A, P_A = 3 x 10^5 Pa, V_A = 1 x 10^-3 m^3.
From the p-V diagram: At state C, P_C = 1 x 10^5 Pa, V_C = 3 x 10^-3 m^3.
Number of moles n and gas constant R remain constant.
Use relation (P_A V_A)/T_A = (P_C V_C)/T_C due to constant n and R.
Substitute known values into the equation: (3 x 10^5 x 1 x 10^-3)/300.15 = (1 x 10^5 x 3 x 10^-3)/T_C.
Simplify the left side of the equation: 3 x 10^2/300.15.
Equate the simplified left side to the right side: 3 x 10^2/300.15 = 3 x 10^2/T_C.
Determine that the temperature of the gas at state C is 300.15 K.
